title: W√∂chentliche Vorbereitung auf die Seminar-Sitzung
text:
Besprechung in der Sitzung

Was ist die zentrale theoretische L√ºcke in bisherigen Konzepten, die von Klimmt und Rieger (2021) beschrieben wird, und wie schlagen die Autor:innen vor, diese zu schlie√üen?

Zentrale Frage: Warum ist eine Rezeptionssituation f√ºr eine bestimmte Person bedeutsam ist: ‚ÄúWhat is missing in such current understanding of meaningful entertainment experiences is an approach to the user‚Äôs subjective, individual construction of meaning. ‚ÄúWhat is the meaning that appears to viewer X when watching movie Y? How is that meaningful to her/him?‚Äù‚Äù
Individuelle sinnkonstruktion der rezipient:in
Fokus auf Mediennutzer:in, nicht nur auf den Medieninhalt (Interaktion)
‚ÄúCentral to our proposition is that each member of the audience brings her or his personal biography to the process of entertainment consumption, and that meaningfulness will arise if some element of the chosen message resonates with some relevant part of a user‚Äôs personality, subjective history, and/or situation in life‚Äù
‚ÄúWe build on these perspectives to conceptualize experiences of meaningfulness as outcome of media entertainment‚Äôs biographic resonance, that is, the emotionally loaded experience that a received entertainment content has something important to do with one‚Äôs self, one‚Äôs situation, one‚Äôs life history, and/or one‚Äôs (biographically rooted) current questions about life.‚Äù
Im Hinblick auf die Suche nach und das Erleben von Sinnhaftigkeit durch den Einzelnen spielen kritische Lebensereignisse eine wichtige Rolle



Was sind Eigenschaften des Medieninhalts, die biographisches Resonanzerleben ausl√∂sen k√∂nnen?

Charaktere/Medienpersonae

√Ñhnlichkeit zu Rezipient:in; zB Charakterz√ºge, Haltungen/Einstellungen
Door opener, Entdecken von √Ñhnlichkeit erm√∂glicht elaborierte Verabeitung von Informationen

Situationen

Themen√ºbergreifende Beziehungen/Themen, z.B. Besprechung von Krisenthemen -> Allgemeing√ºltige Resonanz (vgl. Fokus auf Inhalte bei Tamborini et al.)
‚ÄúBecause of the increased personal involvement, he or she will mobilize greater interest, more serious elaboration, and less readiness to remain in a ‚Äúlight-hearted,‚Äù escapistic stance toward the message‚Äù

Entscheidungen

Inspiration durch die Entscheidung der Medienpersona
‚ÄúHence, under conditions of biographic resonance, entertainment portrayals of character decisions can serve as material for audience members‚Äô personal meaning making [past decisions] (Park, 2010) and crisis decision-making [future decisions] (Sweeny, 2008).‚Äù

Metaphern

Anwendung auf komplexe Sacheverhalte des eigenen Lebens
Reduktion von Komplexit√§t
‚Äúthey may show a user a new way of expressing or symbolizing a complex issue related to a life crisis, for instance, or illustrate a more optimistic perspective on how to frame and overcome a challenge in life‚Äù




Wie l√§sst sich das Erleben biographischer Resonanz bei der Mediennutzung beschreiben und warum ist dies f√ºr Mediennutzer:innen bedeutsam?

idR elaborierte Verarbeitung von Informationen, Nachdenken √ºber bspw. die Situation, Entscheidung, Metapher, etc
gemischter Affekt: negativer Affekt durch Erinnerung an negatives Erlebnis aus der eigenen Vergangenheit; Inspiration, wie man mit zuk√ºnftigen Krisen umgehen kann; Erinnerung an die Unterst√ºtzugn durch soziale Kontakte, Weiternetwicklung, Neudentdeckung, Selebstfindung (Hoffnung; Dankbarkeit)
‚ÄúThis perceived connection between elements of the entertainment message and one‚Äôs own biography should make a profound difference for the user‚Äôs experience; because unlike escapist entertainment use and its typical focus on wishful identification, ideal selves and circumstances (e.g., superheroes, extraordinarily attractive people, places, and situations, cf.¬†Katz & Foulkes, 1962), messages that trigger biographic resonance direct the user toward her or his real-life identity, her or his actual self and biographic circumstances.‚Äù

Bew√§ltigung von Krisensituationen

Resonierende Medieninhalte helfen, eine Krisensituation zu verstehen
Resonierende Medieninhalte helfen dabei, auf die √§u√üeren Anforderungen einer Lebenskrise zu reagieren
Resonierende Medieninhalte verdeutlichen die Bedeutung von Familie, Freunden und unterst√ºtzenden Personen in Lebenskrisen
Resonierende Medieninhalte unterst√ºtzen die Affektregulierung und stimulieren Hoffnung
Resonierende Medieninhalte f√∂rdern Ver√§nderungen des Selbstkonzepts und ein Gef√ºhl der Kompetenz
Emotionale Folgen der biografischen Resonanz

negativer Affekt durch Erinnerung an die Lebenskrise
positiver Affekt durch selbsttranszendierende Emotionen wie Hoffnung und Dankbarkeit

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
section: The narrative enjoyment and appreciation rationale
text:
The narrative enjoyment and appreciation rationale
Tamborini et al. (2021)





Socially oriented motivations




care (valuing compassion and reviling harm to others)
fairness (related to the desire for justice, reciprocity, and the punishment of cheaters)
ingroup loyalty (bias favoring the common good of group members and disfavoring rival outsiders)
respecting authority (adhering to social dominance hierarchies and traditions)
purity (the motivation to maintain a wholesome lifestyle free of social contamination)




Self-oriented motivations




competence (the need to be recognized for one‚Äôs personal skills and achievements)
relatedness (the desire to feel close to and connected with others)
autonomy (a desire to feel in control of one‚Äôs life and choices)
hedonism (the desire for physical pleasure)
security (the need for stability and personal safety)
power (an aspiration to control and influence resources and others)




Tamborini, R., Grady, S. M., Baldwin, J., McClaran, N., & Lewis, R. (2021). The narrative enjoyment and appreciation rationale. In P. Vorderer & C. Klimmt (Eds.), The Oxford Handbook of Entertainment Theory (pp.¬†44‚Äì62). Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780190072216.013.3

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Reflective

You would get a good sense of who I am by looking at the content that shows up in my feed.
I feel like the algorithm is tailored specifically to me.
Overall, the algorithm is reflective of who I am and what I care about.
I can see a lot of myself in the content that the algorithm recommends for me.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Multi-faceted

I can see many different kinds of content that are relevant to me on my feed.
I feel like the algorithm creates a unique blend of content for me based on a variety of things I‚Äôm interested in.
Someone looking at my feed would be able to tell I have diverse interests.
My feed shows me content representing a wide variety of things I like.
I feel like the algorithm‚Äôs recommendations for me are quite one-dimensional.*



Reverse-coded items are denoted with an asterisk.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Dynamic

My feed keeps up with my latest interests by showing me new, relevant content.
The content recommended by the algorithm changes to match what I‚Äôm currently interested in.
I feel like the algorithm is quick to catch on when I am interested in a new topic.
I notice that the algorithm tends to get stuck on content I‚Äôm not interested in anymore.*
When I look at my feed, it feels outdated because the content is no longer of interest to me.*



Reverse-coded items are denoted with an asterisk.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Agency

I can influence what shows up on my feed.
I have a good amount of control over what the algorithm shows me.
If I wanted to change what shows up on my feed, I could.
I can‚Äôt do much to change what the algorithm shows me.*
I don‚Äôt have much control over what the algorithm shows me.*



Reverse-coded items are denoted with an asterisk.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Strategic Refinement

I deliberately engage with certain kinds of content to influence what the algorithm shows me.
I decide what to watch, or not to watch, in order to influence what the algorithm thinks I like.
I purposefully don‚Äôt engage with certain kinds of content to refine the algorithm‚Äôs recommendations for me.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Organic Refinement

The algorithm is influenced by the content that I normally engage with.
Interacting with content on my feed improves its ability to recommend content to me.
My everyday behaviors teach the algorithm what content I want to see.
The way I generally interact with content on my feed refines the algorithm‚Äôs recommendations for me.
My behavior does not affect the algorithm‚Äôs recommendations very much.*



Reverse-coded items are denoted with an asterisk.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Refraction

People that I see on my feed remind me of myself.
I feel like I can relate to people on my feed even if I don‚Äôt know them.
I often see parts of myself represented in the people and content I come across through the algorithm.
When I see people show up in my feed, they remind me of myself.
I feel quite different from the people I see on my feed.*



Reverse-coded items are denoted with an asterisk.

title: Der Algorithmus kennt mich (nicht):
text:
Diffracted Belonging

I feel ‚Äúseen‚Äù when the algorithm shows me content from people who are like me.
When I spend time browsing content on my feed, I feel that there are many other people who are similar to me.
The content on my feed makes me feel understood because it shows me people who have similar life experiences as me.
I feel more connected to others when I see content from people like me on my feed.
Seeing people like me on my feed makes me feel like I am not alone.

title: W√∂chentliche Vorbereitung auf die Seminar-Sitzung
text:
Besprechung in der Sitzung

Wie kann man enjoyment und appreciation definieren?
Beide sind Formen von positivem Rezeptionserleben

man kann unterscheiden zwischen affektbasierten und funktionalen Perspektiven auf Unterhaltungserleben
‚ÄúSimply put, positive evaluations resulting from fast, intuitive processing are labeled enjoyment, whereas those resulting from slower, deliberative processes are called appreciation‚Äù

Typische Selbstberichtmessung f√ºr Enjoyment und Appreciation









Dimension
Item Content
English
German




Appreciation
Meaningful
I found this movie to be very meaningful.
Der Film hatte f√ºr mich eine tiefere Bedeutung.


Appreciation
Thought-provoking
The movie was thought provoking.
Der Film hat mich zum Nachdenken angeregt.


Appreciation
Being moved
I was moved by this movie.
Dieser Film hat mich bewegt.


Fun
Fun
It was fun for me to watch this movie.
Es hat mir Spa√ü gemacht, diesen Film anzuschauen.


Fun
Good time
I had a good time watching this movie.
Ich hatte beim Anschauen dieses Films eine gute Zeit.


Fun
Entertaining
The movie was entertaining.
Der Film war unterhaltsam.



Schneider, F. M., Bartsch, A., & Oliver, M. B. (2019). Factorial Validity and Measurement Invariance of the Appreciation, Fun, and Suspense Scales across US-American and German Samples. Journal of Media Psychology, 31(3), 149‚Äì156. https://doi.org/10.1027/1864-1105/a000236


Was bedeutet dual-process logic?
Intuitive, automatische Informationsverarbeitung (System 1) vs.¬†bewusste, √ºberlegte Informationsverarbeitung (System 2).
System 1 arbeitet schnell und ohne bewusste Anstrengung und basiert oft auf heuristischen und assoziativen Prozessen, w√§hrend System 2 langsamer, kontrollierter und analytischer arbeitet und komplexere Entscheidungs- und Denkaufgaben bew√§ltigt. Man geht davon aus, dass diese Systeme einen grundlegenden Einfluss darauf haben, wie wir Informationen verarbeiten, Entscheidungen treffen und Probleme l√∂sen, wobei System 1 anf√§lliger f√ºr kognitive Verzerrungen und System 2 logischer und regelbasierter ist.


Welches sind sozial ausgerichtete, welche auf das Selbst ausgerichtete Motivationen f√ºr die Mediennutzung?
Socially oriented motivations






Motivations




care (valuing compassion and reviling harm to others)


fairness (related to the desire for justice, reciprocity, and the punishment of cheaters)


ingroup loyalty (bias favoring the common good of group members and disfavoring rival outsiders)


respecting authority (adhering to social dominance hierarchies and traditions)


purity (the motivation to maintain a wholesome lifestyle free of social contamination)



Self-oriented motivations






Motivations




competence (the need to be recognized for one‚Äôs personal skills and achievements)


relatedness (the desire to feel close to and connected with others)


autonomy (a desire to feel in control of one‚Äôs life and choices)


hedonism (the desire for physical pleasure)


security (the need for stability and personal safety)


power (an aspiration to control and influence resources and others)





Wie h√§ngen diese Motivationen mit dem enjoyment und appreciation von Narrativen zusammen?
‚ÄúThree message features are critical in determining which system governs response:


the absence or presence of intuition conflict,


the extent to which intuitions are made salient in the narrative (i.e., those emphasized in the plot), and


the satisfaction of those salient intuitions, where satisfaction refers to reward for acts that conform to intuitions, and thwarting refers to the inverse of this.‚Äù


‚ÄúFirst, when all salient intuitive needs are satisfied, entertainment is intuitively processed and positively experienced, free from any thought that might challenge this appraisal. The NEAR calls this enjoyment. Second, when the most salient intuitive needs but not all salient intuitive needs are satisfied, entertainment is deliberatively processed and positively experienced, but positive appraisal comes with uncertainty. The NEAR refers to this as appreciation.‚Äù
